SCHWERTE, Germany (Reuters) - Germany’s Social Democrats (SPD) will clash over policy with Angela Merkel in the next government, the main candidate to lead the center-left party said on Wednesday, adding that the conservative chancellor was approaching the end of her career.
Seeking to rally support for a deal to renew an alliance with Merkel’s conservative bloc that SPD members have to ratify in a postal ballot, Andrea Nahles said the party could reinvent itself by fighting for its policies in a coalition government.

Amid deep rank-and-file divisions over the coalition deal and the distribution of ministerial posts, and facing a slump in opinion polls, SPD leaders are trying to convince 464,000 party members to endorse the accord with Merkel in a ballot on which her fourth term depends.
Mr Schulz said he was handing over to a left-winger, Andrea Nahles, with immediate effect. However, SPD members have to vote on the change on 22 April.

@healther seems to have explained what is happening. Merkel got a bit closer to forming a new government today. There is logic in the SPD wanting to avoid being junior coalition members and getting the blame for unpopular policies and no credit for popular policies, but will standing out this time around help them? Presumably that would only work if the CDU actually formed a government or a new election was called and the SPD got enough votes so that it could lead a coalition.  A CDU minority government is (I suppose) possible, but it is not self evident that would increase support for the SDP, as a minority government would be fragile and some voters might think the SDP had just chickened out. I doubt that Germans would want an Italian style system where weak governments get replaced every few months (as they used to). The real problem is having the AfD getting votes, but the CDU ruling out a coalition with them. If other parties (those other than the AfD) will not join a CDU coalition, and these other parties do not have enough seats to form a majority themselves the only remaining option is a minority government.

Merkel Reaches 'Grand Coalition' Breakthrough with Social Democrats (FT)
Angela Merkel's conservative bloc and its left-of-center rivals the Social Democrats have achieved a breakthrough in exploratory talks on forming a new "grand coalition", raising hopes of an end to the political deadlock that has gripped Germany since inconclusive elections in September. The breakthrough came during talks this morning between Merkel, Horst Seehofer, leader of the Bavarian CSU, and Martin Schulz, the Social Democrat chief. The three will now recommend to their parties that they start official coalition talks. The euro rallied after the terms of the coalition deal emerged, reaching its highest level against the dollar since January 2015. The SPD will first have to give the green light for formal coalition talks, and any coalition agreement will also have to be voted on by its members. Yet today's breakthrough is still the first concrete sign that Germany's long-running political crisis may finally be coming to an end.

One interesting wrinkle in the semantics of the question: as pointed by @Khalid, the road to new elections passes through 3 votes in the Bundestag, the last one of which is just by relative majority. Yet the German President is not bound by this third vote - he can still dissolve the parliament even if the Chancellor is approved. So if the political parties agree to  go this route, it is possible that Merkel is technically elected as a Chancellor yet there are new elections. The GJO should clarify how would they score the question in this case as well.

We could be getting into semantics with this question. If a new election takes place it will (almost certainly) be in 2018. 2018 is "after the 2017 Bundestage election", so in one reading of the meaning of the question if Mrs Merkel gets elected chancellor anytime in the future the answer to the question will be "yes". But an alternative meaning of "after the 2917 election" could be "as a consequence or result of the 2017 election" which an election in 2018 would not be.

Angela Merkel appeared to be powering ahead today to a fourth term as chancellor of Germany, after her rival Martin Schulz failed to halt her advance in a crucial televised debate three weeks before elections. Yesterday's prime-time TV clash had been billed as Schulz's last chance to sway a decisive share of voters to his cause and halt a devastating popularity slide. The base rate for incumbency success of chancellors seeking re-election in Germany is 0,82 for 1949 to present and 0,71 for the period 1990 to present.
To date, the best way to have an eye on the public opinion seems to be poll aggregating making probabilistic judgments on who would win. Two such instruments are available:
-	https://www.inwt-statistics.de/blog-artikel-lesen/wahlprognose-fuer-die-bundestagswahl-2017.html#Prognose (German)
-	http://www.thecrosstab.com/germany-2017/ (English)
-	Raw data is provided here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_polling_for_the_German_federal_election,_2017
The German page by INWT Statistics is also modeling the probability that Merkel can stay German Chancellor: to date this is 84,5 per cent. However there are some arguments this could be too high and some that this could be too low.
84,5 per cent is too low:
-	The poll aggregators model a red-red-green coalition (SPD-LEFT-Greens) as more likely than a Grand Coalition of CDU und SPD, if both were possible. This is a strong assumption since – first – voters do not prefer the red-red-green coalition and both, SPD and the LEFT, have a very considerable disagreement among leaders and rank-and-file to go ahead with such a coalition. If possible, I would say that the chances are – at best – 50 percent for this coalition to be formed. Schultz clearly signals to voters that he does not want form a coalition with the LEFT in the first place.
-	Given the fact that the SPD has to make a statement on coalition options and given the clear impression from several regional elections that red-red-green coalition is not preferred by the voters, it seems likely that this route to the Chancellorship is completely down for Martin Schulz, the candidate for Chancellorship of the SPD. The only route that he then has is a coalition with the Liberals and the Greens. But: If this kind of a ‘traffic light coalition’ would be possible and given that the CDU would have the biggest seat share (very, very likely: 99 percent) a CDU-Liberal-Green coalition would be possible, either. The Liberals and the Greens would be in the position to decide which side they would join and which of the candidates would become German Chancellor. Greens tend to the SPD camp, Liberals tend to the CDU camp. That would very likely end up in a stalemate. Consequence: Grand Coalition, Chancellor: Merkel.
-	Given the enormous success of the Liberals in the regional elections in North Rhine Westphalia (12+ percent), it could become more likely than pollsters currently measure that a CDU-Liberal government could be formed (if so, with a very tiny majority). So it seems that Merkel will have another realistic option to stay Chancellor – beside the Grand Coalition.
-	Merkel is probably least prone to political scandals among the Western leaders and candidates. A Fillon-like scandal in Germany seems very unlikely, but Merkel not even had to witness a scandal like some of her Cabinet members that – nevertheless – would not lead to their resignation. And this holds true if one looks back all the years she is in German politics. That makes her approval ratings and her electoral performance a reliable factor to count on.
-	Schulz and the SPD lack the magic triangle: a harmonizing combination of (1) Candidate, (2) an issue that voters have an interest in and (3) a favorable media agenda.
However, 84,5 per cent could be too high:
-	There is so much time until elections take place… Many things can happen. Merkel almost lost safe elections in 2005 against the – incumbent – Gerhard Schröder. Scandals among rank-and-file are always possible, particularly in the CDU – even if they seem to be harmless in international perspective.
-	It is very likely that the current offspring of the CDU and Liberal polls will normalize a bit an SPD will gain momentum. Too, it is likely that Schulz will find an issue and – may be, may be – media agenda will support him (most journalist in Germany lean toward the left side of the political spectrum).
-	It would be very awkward for Merkel and the CDU if there would be a terrorist attack with an Islamic background or something similar: a series of violent crimes with nationwide media coverage committed by refugees or other foreigners (because people blame Merkel personally for the refugee inflow in 2015; and national security and law-and-order is a unique selling point of the CDU). If refugee crisis would rebound it would be disastrous for the CDU. However, it is kind of the absurd situation in Germany in the Merkel era that such events would not be to the advantage of the SPD; rather, the Alternative for Germany (AfD) would profit from such events. – Even under these very unfavorable circumstances for the CDU: the Chancellor is very likely to stay Merkel!
All in all, it seems to date, that Merkel is fairly well ‘priced’ with 88 to 90 percent probability to stay Chancellor of Germany after the next parliamentary elections.

It should be remembered that it is NOT the German federal election that will decide whether Merkel will be elected chancellor. To all those who complain about how strange the American electoral system is: You haven't seen the Germans yet. It is the Bundestag, not the people, who decide who Germany's most powerful member of state is. The Bundestag is elected by the people, but they can vote for whomever they please. Usually, they vote according to party affiliation. Now, people might think that it's really a close race between CDU and SPD. However, that's where you would be mistaken, since the members of the Bundestag are decided by districts, (similar to the US's states electing the president). And, just like in America, you can have more Bundestags-people even without having the popular vote.

Well, there is a lot to consider here. There are two "mechanisms" of German politics that are essential for being elected as a Chancellor. First there is the election of course. The party with the most votes obtains the right to ... to select the Chancellor? Not directly. It's the right to form a coalition in order to get the majority in the German Bundestag and then to elect the Chancellor. As a consequence it gets a bit complicated here. Angela Merkel not only need to get the most votes but also a coalition partner to stay in power. Therefore she might be in a difficult situation after the election but her main competitor Martin Schulz is likely to be, too. There are different scenarios possible.

Germany’s Social Democrats (SPD) are euphoric about the formal elevation on Sunday of their new leader, Martin Schulz. He has promised “to fight while standing, sitting, or lying; on water, land and in the air” to become the next chancellor in the election on September 24th. His advantage, as former president of the European Parliament, is that his views on domestic issues are little known, making him difficult to attack. This only adds to the suspense over his strategy, which he will unveil at the party gathering in Berlin, for challenging Angela Merkel, the incumbent. A new poll shows them tied in popularity at 41% each. But the excitement is unlikely to last. Germans don’t elect the chancellor directly. The SPD is at 23% in the polls, while Mrs Merkel’s centre-right bloc leads at 36%. And at present there seems no way the SPD could form a coalition that could remove Mrs Merkel from power

Nine months out, I think Merkel's chances of winning are high, but so were Hillary Clinton's. She has about a 10 point lead despite outcry on the right and a crumbling EU, and it is hard to see an alternative to succeed her barring some major disaster. The SPD is more pro-EU and migrant than Merkel herself, and I think it will be difficult for Schulz (untried in Germany) to undermine the powerful Merkel's left flank. I believe that remembrance of the Nazi era is more poignant in Germany than elsewhere and the far-right identity politics of the AfD will not be as effective as in say France or Britain, especially as recent leaks indicate a more rightist tack in Merkel's campaign. An alliance between right and leftist groups to bring down Merkel is very improbable. Additionally, the EU has largely been a boon to Germany and an expression of German power, and I think many Germans will rally around its champion against what can be seen as damaging exogenous populist forces.

1) CDU + AfD 
2) CDU + SDP (+ Green + FDP - neither needed)
3) SDP + Left + Green (+ FDP) + a bit of luck 
Both main parties probably want to keep AfD and Left out of government, so on current polling option 2 is the likely coalition - question then becomes relative power of CDU & SDP in negotiations.
